org.jcvi.jillion.core.datastore

Class DataStoreUtil

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.jcvi.jillion.core.datastore.DataStoreUtil

  • public final class DataStoreUtil
extends Object
    Utility class containing static factory methods to adapt DataStores into another types of DataStores.
    Author:
    dkatzel

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class and Description
      static interface  DataStoreUtil.AdapterCallback<F,T>
      AdapterCallback is a callback method that can convert one type into another.
      static interface  DataStoreUtil.CacheableDataStore<T>
      CacheableDataStore is an interface that is used for Cached objects created by createNewCachedDataStore(Class, DataStore, int).

    • Method Detail

      • adapt

        public static <T> DataStore<T> adapt(Map<String,T> map)
        Create a new DataStore instance using the data of the given Map. The entries in the given map are copied into a new private map so any future manipulations to the input map will not affect the returned DataStore. The order of entries return by the DataStore.idIterator() and DataStore.iterator() are determined by the iteration order of input Map at the time this method is called.
        Type Parameters:
        T - The type of Records in the DataStore.
        Parameters:
        map - the map to adapt into a DataStore.
        Returns:
        a new DataStore instance.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if map is null, or if any keys or values in the map are null.

      • adapt

        public static <T,D extends DataStore<T>> D adapt(Class<D> datastoreInterface,
                                                 Map<String,T> map)
        Create a new DataStore instance of the given type D using the data of the given map. The entries in the given map are copied into a new private map so any future manipulations to the input map will not affect the returned DataStore. The order of entries return by the DataStore.idIterator() and DataStore.iterator() are determined by the iteration order of input Map at the time this method is called.

        This factory method uses the Java Dynamic Proxy classes to create a new implementation of the given interface which uses the map as a backing store. This factory class can only implement methods that conform to the DataStore interface, if the given DataStore interface has extension methods that are not part of the core DataStore interface then trying to call those methods will throw an illegalArgumentException.

        Type Parameters:
        T - the type of record in the returned dataStore and the type of the values in the given Map.
        D - the type of DataStore to return (created using a dynamic proxy)
        Parameters:
        datastoreInterface - the interface to proxy; can not be null.
        map - the map to adapt into a datastore; can not be null.
        Returns:
        a new DataStore instance which implements the given datastoreInterface and contains the records in the input Map.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if datastoreInterface is null, map is null, or if any keys or values in the map are null.
        IllegalArgumentException - if the given datastoreInterface is not a public interface or violates the constraints set by Proxy.getProxyClass(ClassLoader, Class...)
        See Also:
        Proxy.getProxyClass(ClassLoader, Class...)

      • adapt

        public static final <T,D extends DataStore<T>> D adapt(Class<D> datastoreInterface,
                                                       DataStore<T> delegate)
        Create a new DataStore instance of the given type D using which wraps the given DataStore in a new Dynamic Proxy class which mimics the desired DataStore. This is useful to convert a DataStore<T> into a different DataStore subinterface which has the same DataStore.get(String) signature. All method calls on the returned proxy Datastore are derived by delegating to the input DataStore. Closing the input DataStore will also close this Proxy DataStore and vice versa. The order of entries return by the DataStore.idIterator() and DataStore.iterator() are determined by the the iteration order of input DataStore.

        This factory method uses the Java Dynamic Proxy classes to create a new implementation of the given interface which wraps the input DataStore as a backing store. This factory class can only implement methods that conform to the input DataStore interface, if the return DataStore interface has extension methods that are not part of the input DataStore interface then trying to call those methods will throw an illegalArgumentException.

        Type Parameters:
        T - the type of record both the input and output dataStores.
        D - the type of DataStore to return (created using a dynamic proxy)
        Parameters:
        datastoreInterface - the interface to proxy; can not be null.
        delegate - the original DataStore to adapt into a different type of DataStore.
        Returns:
        a new DataStore instance which implements the given datastoreInterface and contains the records in the input DataStore.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if datastoreInterface is null, delegate is null.
        NullPointerException - if datastoreInterface is null, map is null, or if any keys or values in the map are null.
        IllegalArgumentException - if the given datastoreInterface is not a public interface or violates the constraints set by Proxy.getProxyClass(ClassLoader, Class...)
        See Also:
        Proxy.getProxyClass(ClassLoader, Class...)

      • adapt

        public static final <F,T,D extends DataStore<T>> D adapt(Class<D> datastoreInterface,
                                                         DataStore<F> delegate,
                                                         Function<F,T> callback)
        Create a new DataStore instance of the given type T using the data of the given DataStore which contains records of the correct type. This factory method uses the Java Proxy classes to create a new implementation of the given interface which then delegates all calls to the given datastore. This factory class can only implement methods that conform to the DataStore interface, if the given interface has extension methods that do not exist in the given delegated DataStore, then trying to call those methods will throw an illegalArgumentException.
        Type Parameters:
        F - the "From" type. This is the type that the original datastore has its type as
        T - the "To" type. This is the type that we want to convert the type F into which may require method calls or new object creation.
        D - the Database interface type we want the returned datastore to mimic.
        Parameters:
        datastoreInterface - the interface to proxy; can not be null.
        delegate - the original DataStore to adapt into a different type of DataStore; can not be null.
        callback - an instance of DataStoreUtil.AdapterCallback used to adapt records of type <F> into records of type <T>; can not be null.
        Returns:
        a new DataStore instance which implements the given datastoreInterface.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if datastoreInterface is null, delegate is null, or if callback is null.

      • chain

        public static <T,D extends DataStore<T>> DataStore<T> chain(Collection<D> datastores)
        Create a new DataStore that contains the entire contents of each of the input DataStores. The order of the input DataStores is the order that these DataStores will be chained together. This results in the following contract:
        • Calls to DataStore.get(String) or DataStore.contains(String) will check each DataStore for the given record until the record is found or all DataStores are checked.
        • Calls to DataStore.getNumberOfRecords() will return a combined total over all the datastores.
        • Calls to DataStore.iterator() and DataStore.idIterator() will chain the iterators of each DataStore one after the other. When the first datastore's iterator is finished, then StreamingIterator.next() will move onto the iterator from the next DataStore etc.
        • Closing the returned DataStore will close all the input DataStores

        This is a useful method for combining several different DataStore objects to appear as a single DataStore. For example combining several sequence input files (possibly in different file formats) which have been parsed into DataStores can be adapted into a single chained DataStore for processing. The fact that the sequence data comes from multiple files (objects) has been abstracted away.

        This factory method uses the Java Proxy classes to create a new implementation of the given interface which then delegates all calls to the given datastore. This factory class can only implement methods that conform to the DataStore interface, if the given interface has extension methods that do not exist in the given delegated DataStore, then trying to call those methods will throw an illegalArgumentException.

        Type Parameters:
        T - the type of record both the input and output dataStores.
        D - the type of DataStore to return (created using a dynamic proxy)
        Parameters:
        datastores - the datastores to chain together; can not be null or empty.
        Returns:
        a new instance of type D.

      • chain

        public static <T,D extends DataStore<T>> D chain(Class<D> datastoreInterface,
                                                 Collection<D> datastores)
        Create a new DataStore that contains the entire contents of each of the input DataStores. The order of the input DataStores is the order that these DataStores will be chained together. This results in the following contract:
        • Calls to DataStore.get(String) or DataStore.contains(String) will check each DataStore for the given record until the record is found or all DataStores are checked.
        • Calls to DataStore.getNumberOfRecords() will return a combined total over all the datastores.
        • Calls to DataStore.iterator() and DataStore.idIterator() will chain the iterators of each DataStore one after the other. When the first datastore's iterator is finished, then StreamingIterator.next() will move onto the iterator from the next DataStore etc.
        • Closing the returned DataStore will close all the input DataStores

        This is a useful method for combining several different DataStore objects to appear as a single DataStore. For example combining several sequence input files (possibly in different file formats) which have been parsed into DataStores can be adapted into a single chained DataStore for processing. The fact that the sequence data comes from multiple files (objects) has been abstracted away.

        This factory method uses the Java Proxy classes to create a new implementation of the given interface which then delegates all calls to the given datastore. This factory class can only implement methods that conform to the DataStore interface, if the given interface has extension methods that do not exist in the given delegated DataStore, then trying to call those methods will throw an illegalArgumentException.

        Type Parameters:
        T - the type of record both the input and output dataStores.
        D - the type of DataStore to return (created using a dynamic proxy)
        Parameters:
        datastoreInterface - the interface to proxy; can not be null.
        datastores - the datastores to chain together; can not be null or empty.
        Returns:
        a new instance of type D.

      • createNewCachedDataStore

        public static <D extends DataStore<?>> D createNewCachedDataStore(Class<D> c,
                                                                  D delegate,
                                                                  int cacheSize)
        Create a new Dynamic Proxy wrapping the given DataStore. The returned object is similar to the wrapped dataStore except all DataStore.get(String) results are cached in an Least Recently Used (LRU) SoftReference cache of the specified size and an additional interface, DataStoreUtil.CacheableDataStore has been added to the list of interfaces the returned DataStore implements. This will keep the Most recent cacheSize records in memory as long as the JVM doesn't need the memory for other things.
        Type Parameters:
        D - interface of DataStore to proxy
        Parameters:
        c - class object of D
        delegate - instance of DataStore
        cacheSize - the size of the cache used to keep most recently "gotten" objects.
        Returns:
        a proxy instance of type D which wraps the given delegate and caches all results returned by get in an LRU cache.
        See Also:
        clearCacheFrom(DataStore), isACachedDataStore(DataStore)

      • clearCacheFrom

        public static void clearCacheFrom(DataStore<?> cachedDataStore)
        Clears the cache from a DataStore created by this utility class if it has a cache; This method does nothing if the given datastore is not a DataStoreUtil.CacheableDataStore.
        Parameters:
        cachedDataStore - a DataStore that was created by this utility (implements DataStoreUtil.CacheableDataStore.
        See Also:
        isACachedDataStore(DataStore)

      • isACachedDataStore

        public static boolean isACachedDataStore(DataStore<?> cachedDataStore)
        Is the given DataStore a Cached DataStore created by createNewCachedDataStore(Class, DataStore, int).
        Parameters:
        cachedDataStore - a DataStore that may or may not have been created by this utility (implements DataStoreUtil.CacheableDataStore.
        Returns:
        true if this is a DataStoreUtil.CacheableDataStore; false otherwise.
